title: 104_hr4162
content: The Act titled "Continued Participation Pension Act of 1996" allows certain individuals to continue participating in defined benefit plans under the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974. The Continued Participation Pension Act of 1996 allows qualified beneficiaries to continue accruing benefits in a defined benefit plan after a qualifying event, ensuring they do not lose eligibility to accrue benefits. The Continued Participation Pension Act of 1996 allows qualified beneficiaries to continue accruing benefits in a defined benefit plan after a qualifying event, ensuring they do not lose eligibility to accrue benefits. The period of continued participation is considered service with the employer for determining nonforfeitability and benefit accrual. Earnings and forfeitures are not included in determining liabilities and obligations of the plan. The Continued Participation Pension Act of 1996 allows beneficiaries to continue accruing benefits in a defined benefit plan after a qualifying event. Earnings and forfeitures are excluded in determining plan liabilities. Liabilities are allocated by the plan sponsor or the last employer before the qualifying event in a multiemployer plan. The period of continued participation lasts from the qualifying event date until the earliest of specified dates. The Continued Participation Pension Act of 1996 allows beneficiaries to continue accruing benefits in a defined benefit plan after a qualifying event. The period of participation extends from the qualifying event date until the earliest of specified dates based on retirement age, employer plan termination, or failure to pay contributions. The Continued Participation Pension Act of 1996 allows qualified beneficiaries to continue accruing benefits in a defined benefit plan by funding any obligations of the plan. The plan must allocate applicable contributions from employer and employee contributions to qualified beneficiaries. The Continued Participation Pension Act of 1996 allows qualified beneficiaries to receive benefits from employer and employee contributions in the same manner as other beneficiaries. Benefit accruals from voluntary employee contributions are only provided if available prior to a qualifying event. The Continued Participation Pension Act of 1996 allows qualified beneficiaries to receive benefits from employer and employee contributions. Benefit accruals from voluntary employee contributions are provided only if available prior to a qualifying event. The contribution made by the qualified beneficiary during continued participation is limited to 102 percent of the applicable contribution for the period. The Continued Participation Pension Act of 1996 allows qualified beneficiaries to receive benefits from employer and employee contributions. The contribution made by the qualified beneficiary during continued participation is limited to 102 percent of the applicable contribution for the period, with the option to make monthly installments. The election period begins before benefits accrual would cease without continued participation. The Continued Participation Pension Act of 1996 allows qualified beneficiaries to continue receiving benefits from employer and employee contributions. The election period for continued participation must begin before benefits accrual would cease and last at least 90 days. Any qualified beneficiary's election of continued participation also applies to other beneficiaries affected by the qualifying event. The Continued Participation Pension Act of 1996 allows qualified beneficiaries to continue receiving benefits from employer and employee contributions. An election of continued participation must be made before benefits accrual would cease and last at least 90 days. This provision does not apply to defined benefit plans with fewer than 20 employees. Definitions include the applicable contribution and the term 'qualified beneficiary'. The Continued Participation Pension Act of 1996 allows qualified beneficiaries to continue receiving benefits based on actuarial value of benefit accruals. A qualified beneficiary is defined as any beneficiary under the plan before a qualifying event, which must occur within seven years of the participant reaching normal retirement age. The Continued Participation Pension Act of 1996 allows qualified beneficiaries to continue receiving benefits if certain events occur within seven years of the participant reaching normal retirement age, such as termination of employment or death. The Continued Participation Pension Act of 1996 applies to plan years starting on or after July 1, 1996. For defined benefit plans under collective bargaining agreements ratified before the Act's enactment, the rule does not apply until the last agreement terminates or January 1, 2000.
